text: The man lets himself into a large room that looks like Mi Control. He pours himself a cup of coffee. It is the week and the place is empty. No one has been there to see the displays flashing a distinctive shape -- a pulse followed a series of echoes.
The man looks up at the screen, then DROPS his cup of cof
The Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory headquarters at Caltech is a frenzy of activity. POSTDOCS and RESEARCHERS huddle around monitors and printouts, arg
ANSEN, 60s, the director of LIGO, walks through the frenz A postdoc hands him a printout: a pulse followed by echoe
Ansen steps into the relative calm of a large, sunlit off which overlooks a grassy stretch of Caltech's campus.
His ASSISTANT, 30s, is on the phone, on hold. He looks up at Ansen as he enters.
I'm on hold with the INS.
Don't you think we should double check the triangulation before we
We have double checked it.
Someone finally picks up the line.
Yes. I'm trying to reach- (pause, listens) No, I don't think you understand how serious this is.
Because if you did, we'd be having this conversation in person.
He listens for a moment, then hangs up the phone, confuse
What did they say?
They said we should look out the window.
Ansen steps to the window and looks out:
In the courtyard below, coeds are scrambling to get out o the way as a military helicopter sets down in the middle the quad and dozens of ARMED FEDERAL AGENTS converge on h building. 3.
Ansen sits, alone, on one side of a conference table.
The other side is filled with GOVERNMENT MEN -- NSA mostl some DIA. The door opens and his assistant steps in. Arme guards pat him down, then shove him into a seat.
Is that really necessary?
One of the NSA agents leans forward.
You've been complaining for years that the government doesn't take your project seriously enough, Doctor.
You can't have it both ways.
Ansen motions to his assistant, who turns on a projector. On-screen, we see the familiar pulse and echoes.
Yesterday morning, our facility in Hanford identified this signal: a neutron star colliding with a supermassive black hole. We went through the last year's data and triangulated the source.
The pulse is translated into a crude animatic of a neutro star circling into the black hole.
We know that, Doctor. What we don't know is why, according to your numbers, this event took place right here in our own solar system.
Suddenly, the image overlays the sun, the earth, and the rest of our solar system around the black hole.
It didn't. Because if it had we'd all be dead by now.
On-screen, Jupiter, then the Earth and the inner planets consumed by the black hole. Only the sun survives, pulled into orbit around its new master.
Which leaves only one explanation: The signal traveled through a
wormhole. A gateway to a distant corner of the universe. The black hole is on the far side.
On-screen, the black hole system is removed to a distant corner, connected to ours by a tunnel through space-time. gravity wave from the collision travels through the tunne
I've read your book, Doctor. You said that wormholes are impossible.
There is nothing quite as satisfying as being proved utterly wrong.
I said that a wormhole couldn't exist naturally. Not for more than a few billionths of a second. It would have to be... stabilized.
Stabilized by what?
Ansen pauses, unsure. His assistant steps in to his defen
We don't have any way to answer that question.
You're not under peer review here, Doctor. I don't care about your reputation. I need to know how that thing got there. Now.
Ansen finally speaks up.
If you're worried about an invasion, I would start drafting the articles of surrender.
Whoever they are, if they can build a wormhole, they could erase us in the blink of an eye. Luckily, that also means we have nothing they could be interested in.
Then why is it there? 5.
I don't know. Maybe it's an invitation. A chance to commune with an advanced species.
The assistant, embarrassed, looks down. The agent notices
You don't agree?
No. I don't think we can assume an alien intelligence built the wormhole.
But the opportunity it represents is incredible. We could explore parts of the universe we never dreamt of reaching in our lifetimes.
The agent exchanges a look with one of his colleagues, wh steps out of the room.
We need to get back to work. I have a conference call with our European partners in fifteen minutes.
We severed the connections to your European partners this morning.
You can't do that. The Europeans put up some of the funding...
We'll send them a check.
Your project is now classified under the State Secrets Act.
He steps out the door, leaving the men alone. The assista outraged, turns back to his boss.
They can't keep this a secret. You know that. Sooner or later...
The younger man looks down, embarrassed, as he notices th tears are rolling down the older man's cheeks. 6.
I don't care about that. I've spent my whole life being afraid we would wipe ourselves out before this moment arrived. We've made so many mistakes, I wasn't sure we'd make it...
The assitant realizes that the old man is weeping for joy Relief.
But this will change everything. Fifty years from now, nothing will be the same.
The older man looks at the simulation on the screen of th tiny link between our galaxy and another.
Corn. As far as the eye can see.
A large old diesel tour bus is parked by the side of a di road, smoke pouring out of its open hood. A dozen MEN in BASEBALL UNIFORMS are standing around the front of the bu
A battered PICKUP pulls up, and a MAN, 30s, gets out, lea his two SONS in the car. This is COOPER. He joins the ballplayers staring at the lifeless diesel engine.
Seized up on us.
Long way to come by bus. I thought you guys would have a plane.
We did. Ran out of parts for it. You know anything about diesels?
A little.
Cooper steps to the engine compartment.
The ballplayer notices Cooper's two boys, TOM, 15, and MU 10, watching them. He wanders over. 7.
You think your dad's going to be able to help us out?
Murph, a filth-encrusted kid with a black eye, smiles at ballplayer.
My dad can fix anything.
Except maybe your fastball.
The ballplayer frowns: smartass kid.
After a moment under the hood, Cooper signals to the driv who tries the engine. It turns over once, then STARTS.
Sure appreciate the help.
You don't make it, my boys won't get to see you lose.
The ballplayers load up into the bus and as it pulls away we can see the logo painted across the back of the bus fo the first time:
Earth spins, lazily. From this height, it looks much the same as it has done for thousands of years.
Suddenly, a tiny black object appears, racing toward Eart
The object SMASHES into a large satellite and races onwar Behind it, the satellite spins out of orbit in a cloud of fragments.
An old minor league stadium. The stands are barely halfwa full. Cooper, his boys, and Cooper's father-in-law, DONAL 60s, have a row to themselves behind the dugout.
Murph offers his grandpa some popcorn.
Popcorn at a ball game is unnatural. I want a hot dog. 8.
What's a hot dog?
Suddenly, play stops on the field below as the players an fans look up at the night sky:
A bright blue streak is tearing across it. It's beautiful
Is that a comet, Dad?
(shakes his head) Satellite. Big one. Probably Chinese.
Everyone watches the fireworks as the satellite burns up the upper atmosphere.
After a moment, play resumes -- it's a pretty show, but everyone has seen it plenty of times before.
Down on the field, the Dodgers' catcher misses an easy po fly and the Yankees load the bases. Donald looks disguste
Cooper guides his truck along a potholed road. His father in-law is riding shotgun; the boys are sleeping in the ba
Those clowns would get their asses handed to them by the ballplayers I grew up watching.
You ruin it for the boys when you talk like that.
I'm not doing my grandkids any favors by lying to them. They're growing up watching lousy baseball.
They didn't have any baseball at all when I was a kid.
That shuts the old man up for now. They drive on in silen
The sun is gently landing on the horizon, painting the se of corn around Cooper's modest house gold. Cooper walks o of his house, still eating his breakfast.
Donald is on the porch, looking at a black clouds of smok in the distance. The neighboring fields are BURNING.
Nelson's burning up his crops. Found some of the blight on the okra.
Cooper watches the men walking through the fields, settin fire to the crop.
I thought okra wasn't susceptible.
Better safe than sorry. (looks at him) You've got to take the boys to school.
Something wrong with your truck?
Parent-teacher conference day.
Cooper bends his head in dismay.
Be nice to Murph's teacher. She's single, you know.
What does that have to do with anything?
We're supposed to be repopulating the earth. Gotta pull your weight. Besides, the boys could do with a woman in their lives.
The boys run out of the house and pile into the truck. Co pulls away before Donald can continue.
Cooper weaves the car along a dirt road. The kids are arg over an ancient comic book in the back seat. 10.
Cooper turns around to break it up.
BANG -- one of the tires blows out in a foot-deep pothole
Cooper examines the flattened tire. Looks at his older so
Get the spare, Tom.
That is the spare.
All right. We'll use the patch kit.
He moves to the back of the truck. Murph suddenly looks very glum.
I... I think the patch kit might not be there... (off his look) Because I was using it for my bike.
Cooper looks down at the dirt. Sighs.
Murph's law.
What's that?
Tom snorts with laughter. Turns to his dad.
The kid doesn't even know what he was named after...
Cooper shoots Tom a look -- enough.
Murph's law means what can go wrong will go wrong.
Murph, looking hurt, walks off. Cooper turns to his son.
Find something to patch it with.
How am I supposed to do that? 11.
Figure it out. I'm not always going to be here to help you.
Cooper leaves Tom to catch up with his younger son, who i looking out over the river.
Is that really why I'm named Murph, dad?
Listen to me. Murph's law doesn't mean that. It means what can happen will happen. All kinds of things. Good or bad. And that's the way you want it to be.
Why?
Because if nothing ever happened to you then you wouldn't learn anything.
Murph is staring off into the distance. He's heard someth
Murph?
Then Cooper hears it, too. A LOW RUMBLING SOUND. Cooper looks out over the river. Then he turns back and tackles his son to the ground.
Suddenly, a MASSIVE AIRPLANE SOARS overhead, so close the can almost touch it. It bounces the truck on its suspensi then soars off over the fields behind them.
Cooper grabs Murph and races back to the truck. He pulls laptop and an antenna made out of a Pringles can out of t back of the truck. He hands the laptop and antenna to Mur
Get in.
Tom is still standing by the side of the road, wrestling with the jack.
What about the tire?
The truck is SMASHING through the cornfields as fast as C can push it on three good tires. 12.
Murph is hurriedly firing up the laptop and connecting it the directional antenna.
Cooper is straining to see through the cornstalks, scanni the horizon.
To the right, the dark shape of the Russian drone appears flying low over the fields. Cooper jerks the wheel--
The truck BURSTS out of the corn and SPLASHES across the river and into an old, abandoned suburban housing develop in the valley below, planted over with corn.

Half a mile in front of them, the Russian drone is still hugging the ground. It has impossibly long, skinny wings, like an old U-2 surveillance plane, but no cockpit. The tops of its wings are covered in black solar cells.
Murph is fiddling with the computer. His older brother ta the computer from him and fires up emulation software.
It's a Chinese military drone. Solar cells could power an entire farm.
Take the wheel.
Cooper hands Murph the Pringles can antenna.
Keep it pointed right at it, OK?
Murph nods. Tom takes the wheel as his dad works the lapt trying to communicate with the huge Russian drone. The sc fills with Cyrillic characters.
Faster, Tom. I'm losing it.
Tom WEAVES the truck at speed through the old, curved str of the development, past oversized suburban mansions plan over with corn.
They round a corner and come face-to-face with a robot harvester. Tom jerks the wheel to avoid it.
BANG -- the truck loses a wing mirror against the flank o the combine. 13.
Tom guides the truck from street to street, trying to cha a straight path across the fields. The truck BOUNCES as i SMASHES through an old picket fence.
Ahead, the drone is soaring, banking, pulling away.
Cooper is still trying to hack into the drone's control circuitry as they leave the development behind and begin climb into the foothills of the Sierras.
Tom guides the truck along the spine of the hills. The dr soars overhead, making for the white tips of the Sierras.
Cooper is oblivious to the picturesque surroundings as he concentrates on the laptop.
Dad?
Almost got it. Don't slow down.
In front of them, Tom and his brother watch as the drone plummets from view.
Cooper looks up. Ahead, the trail disappears as the edge the hills falls away -- it's a three hundred-foot drop.
Tom locks up the brakes.
The truck skids to a halt inches from a precipitous drop.
Cooper climbs out, holding the laptop. Murph climbs out next to him, still pointing the Pringles can.
We lost it.
No we didn't. 14.
Suddenly, the drone SOARS back over them. Cooper types a couple keys and then moves his fingers across the trackpa The huge drone banks and turns in response.
As the boys watch, Cooper sends the drone soaring high ov them, banking and soaring along the tree-lined sides of t valley, light glinting from the black panels on its back. It's a beautiful sight.
Cooper crouches next to Murph.
You want to give it a whirl?
Murph looks at his dad, wide-eyed. He takes the laptop an moves his fingers gingerly across the pad.
In response, the massive plane banks into a tight turn in the valley below.
For a moment, Murph is in pure heaven, sending the drone dancing through the valley below.
Set her down in the valley -- there, next to the river.
Murph leads the plane in a figure eight and then begins guiding it into a gentle landing in the valley floor belo
The truck limps along the overgrown fairway of a long-def golf course towards the massive hulk of the Russian drone
Cooper and the boys climb down. The valley is silent save for the truck's engine WHEEZING and SPUTTERING as it cool
Cooper runs a hand over the smooth carbon flank of the dr
How long do you think it's been up there, Dad?
Chinese mission control went down same as us, twenty years ago. It's been up there ever since.
What was it doing flying so low?
Cooper reads the information pouring into his laptop. 15.
It was looking for something. Intercepted some kind of signal.
It's been at eighty thousand feet. Sun probably cooked its brain.

Cooper runs his hand along the flank till he finds an acc patch. He pulls out a crowbar and pries open the hatch. Inside, surrounded by a nest of liquid cooling tubes, is small black module -- the drone's auto-pilot.
Cooper looks down at Murph, who is standing at his elbow.
What are you going to do with it?
Reprogram it. Give it something socially responsible to do like drive a combine or a tractor.
Couldn't we just let it go? It's not hurting anyone.
Cooper looks down at his son. Good kid.
We need all the help we can get, Murph. This thing has to adapt, just like the rest of us.
Cooper gently pries the control module out.
It's a small school, so all the kids and parents waiting front know exactly who's driving the pickup truck with ha of a Russian spy plane hanging out of the bed as it pulls
Cooper is ushered into the office. The PRINCIPAL, 40s, an efficient-looking man, shakes his hand.
Good to see you, Mr. Cooper. This is Ms. Kelly, Murph's teacher.
Cooper smiles at Ms. KELLY, 30s, attractive. 16.
So we've gotten Tom's score back. Congratulations. He's going to make an excellent farmer.
The principal slides a carbon copy across the desk to Coo who looks taken aback.
What about college?
The University of California only accepts a few hundred students a year, Mr. Cooper. You have to be realistic.
You're ruling out college for him now? He's only fifteen.
I'm sorry. I'm afraid Tom's score simply isn't high enough.
What are you, about a 36-inch waist?
30-inch inseam?
I'm not sure I see--
You're telling me you need two numbers to measure your own ass, but just one to measure my son's future?
Ms. Kelly stifles a laugh, then, with a look from the principal, takes on the appropriate look of offense.
I understand you're a well-educated man, Mr. Cooper. A scientist?
Engineer.
Frankly, the world doesn't need any more engineers. We didn't run out of trains or television sets or satellites.
We ran out of food. 17.
Cooper leans back. He's not going to win this one.
The world needs farmers, Mr. Cooper. And I'm sure your son Tom is going to make a fine one.
We're a caretaker generation. But things are getting better. Maybe your grandchildren will be able to attend college.
Cooper looks down, swallowing his anger.
Are we done?
One more thing. Ms. Kelly here says that Murph brought a book to school about the lunar landings.
He slides an old textbook with a picture of a rocket on t cover across the desk to Cooper.
One of my old textbooks. Murph liked the pictures.
This is one of the old federal textbooks. We've replaced them with corrected versions.
Corrected?
The new textbooks explain that the Apollo lunar missions were faked in order to bankrupt the Soviet Union.
You don't believe we went to the moon?
I believe it was a brilliant piece of propaganda. The Soviets spent years trying to build rockets and other useless machines.
"Useless machines"? 18.
Cooper looks to the Principal for help. None is forthcomi
Yes, Mr. Cooper. The kind of wastefulness and excess that the 20th century represented. Your children would be better off learning about this planet, rather than reading fantasies about leaving it.
Cooper is silent for a long moment.

One of those useless machines they used to make was called an MRI. If we had any of them left the doctors might have been able to find the cyst in my wife's brain before she died, rather than afterwards. And then my kids could have been raised by two parents, instead of me and their pain-in-the-ass grandfather.
Ms. Kelly's face falls, ashen. Cooper swallows his anger. Most of it, anyway.
You ever consider the best thing for the world and humanity might have been for us to part company?
Cooper gets up to leave.
Cooper climbs into the truck, trying to hold it together. He PUNCHES the wheel.
The radio KEYS to life. He ignores it. Sits for a moment in misery. Finally he picks up the handset.
Got a call from Riggs, down in Galveston. Says some of the tractors you built him went haywire last night.
Just tell him to power down the controllers for a couple minutes.
I did. He wants you to come down in person anyway. Says he found something you should take a look at. 19.
Cooper stares at the wheel. Shakes his head in frustratio
Cooper pulls his truck up to a grimy-looking hangar. Pull a tarp off of an ancient Piper Cub. Checks it over.
Cooper guides the plane along a long sliver of deserted b The radio crackles to life.
Bravo-two-eight, requesting permission to enter your airspace.
Permission granted. Welcome to the sovereign nation of Texas.
Coop hangs up the radio. Banks the plane inland.
Below, a combine harvester fights its way up the dunes, t to reach the beach, its wheels struggling for traction in the soft sand.
A MAN waves up at Cooper's plane as it circles overhead.
Cooper lands the plane on a deserted roadway. Jumps down.
He intercepts one of the combines as it trundles past, tr to reach the dunes. He pops open the cabin.
Inside is a mess of wires hooked into an auto-pilot not u the one he ripped out of the drone. He checks the fault code and resets the computer.
The man jogs over to meet him.
Thanks for coming down. Half of 'em took off last night, looking for something. (points to dunes) Looks like they found it, too. I thought you were the man to see it.
Riggs starts walking up the dune. Cooper follows.
Below, on the beach, a dozen more combines and other farm vehicles are lined up at the tideline, warm gulf water la at their metal flanks. They are circling a deep crater. 20.
As they watch, an ancient autonomous SUB BEACHES itself, trying to reach the crater.
Cooper steps between the waiting machines and peers down into the crater.
At the very bottom is a ROUND BLACK BALL, about a foot ac the same object we saw punch a hole in the side of a satellite. Every few seconds, it emits a distinctive CHIR
Cooper checks his rad meter. A tiny reading -- non-lethal He takes off his watch and hands it to Riggs. Then he sli down into the hole.
The probe CHIRPS as Cooper slides down on top of it. He rubs a hand across its smooth composite bulk.
You think it's an alien?
Cooper wipes sand off of the object, revealing the faint, familiar outline etched into the side of the probe:
The stars and stripes of the old federal government.
Not exactly.
Using a rope and a winch, Cooper hauls the blackened prob out of the crater and onto the beach.
Cooper hefts it up and carries it to the back of his plan
Space probe. Never seen one like it, though. Looks like it's been to hell and back.
The probe CHIRPS as Cooper belts it into the back.
How do you think it wound up here?
Lost, I guess. Guidance satellites would have been shot down by the Chinese twenty years ago.
Cooper looks at the probe for a second, admiring its form 21.
Donald is pouring a bottle of corn beer into a bubbling v of chowder. He turns to watch Cooper work, amused.
The probe has been clamped to the kitchen table. Cooper works at the blackened case with a BLOWTORCH. Cooper give up -- the torch hasn't made a scratch. The probe CHIRPS.
Well I don't know what the hell it's made of, but I can't crack it open.
Good. Clear it off the table so I can serve dinner.
Tom and Murph walk in. Murph's got another black eye.
What happened this time?
I got suspended. Paul said anyone who believed we went to the moon was an idiot. So I hit him.
Good boy. Hand me the scanner.
Murph hands his dad a defibrillator he's modified for the purpose. He attaches the shock pads to the sides of the probe and turns on the power.
Numbers flash across the screen. Cooper hits a button on the controls and it PULSES.
Here we go. Standard NASA encryption. Memory's been damaged. Just noise. Hold on. I've got something.
Cooper unplugs a monitor from his computer and plugs it i the defibrillator. After a moment, an image fills the scr
An ICE-COVERED PLANET nestled in the center of a system impossibly dense with stars. Murph stares, transfixed.
Where is that, dad?
I don't know.
Cooper looks at the probe. 22.
Where the hell did you come from?
Cooper shrugs. Turns off the monitor.
We'll take it down to Tyson's tomorrow and have it melted down. Might be some copper inside.
But what about its mission? What about the information onboard?
There's no one for it to report to. NASA is all gone. I'm sorry, son. It got home too late.
Donald pulls his chowder off the boil and slides the pot unceremoniously onto the table.
The boys have gone to bed. Cooper and Donald are alone at the table. Donald hands Cooper another beer.
I heard your meeting at the school didn't go so well.
Cooper shakes his head in disgust.
Maybe it's better for everyone to forget what they did back then. Reminds us how far we've fallen.
(looks down,) When I was kid, it felt like they made something new every day. Some gadget or idea.
Like every day was Christmas.
But we made a lot of mistakes. Six billion people. Just try to imagine that. Every last one of them trying to have it all.
Donald rolls the bottle of beer in his hands. 23.
The truth is this world isn't that bad. In a lot of ways its better. Tom will be all right, whether he goes to college or not.
It doesn't bother me that he can't go. It bothers me that he doesn't care.

Tom isn't the problem. He fits in this world just fine. You're the one who doesn't fit, Coop. You don't belong here. You were born forty years too late, or forty years too early -- I don't know. My daughter knew it, god bless her. And your kids know it, too.
Donald drains his beer. Walks to the screen door. Stops, one hand on the frame.
You were good at something and you never got a chance to do anything with it. And I'm sorry, Coop. But that's not your kids' fault.
Donald pushes out the screen door.
Cooper looks at his beer. The probe CHIRPS.
Cooper flops down on his bed, fully clothed, exhausted. H stares up at the ceiling. This is his life.
The air is filled with a PIERCING NOISE.
Cooper BOLTS upright. Stumbles out the door.
Cooper's boys are in the hallway, exhausted. Cooper, hold a baseball bat, makes his way down the stairs.
Cooper uses the bat to open the kitchen door.
Cooper steps in, Murph watching from behind him. 24.
The probe is clamped to the table, the chirp replaced wit DEAFENING SCREAM.
Cooper, holding his ears, moves closer to the probe. He hits it with the paddles. No result.

He SMASHES it with the bat. Nothing. He HITS it AGAIN and AGAIN. Finally, the clamps break off chunks of the table and the probe slams to the ground and ROLLS toward the fr door. As it rolls, it STOPS SHRIEKING.
Cooper and the others watch it roll toward the door. It stops at the wall. After a second, it begins SHRIEKING AG
Cooper grabs it and rolls it toward the front door. Once again, the movement shuts it up.
Cooper and his boys roll the probe out of the front door. It BUMPS down the front steps and comes to rest in the di After a moment, the unholy RACKET starts up again.
Cooper keeps rolling it, but it doesn't seem to help. Mur looks up, sees the stars overhead.
Try a different direction.
As they roll the probe in a circle, its SHRIEK stops, the picks up again. Cooper zeroes in on the direction that ke it quiet -- southwest -- and pushes it along in the dirt.
It's a fail-safe. It's going to annoy us into taking it home.
Cooper stops rolling the probe and, after a moment, it be SHRIEKING again.
What are we going to do?
Cooper gets a rope.
We're going to get some sleep.
He begins tying the rope around the probe.
Cooper wakes. He's been sleeping with a pillow wrapped ar his head. The SHRIEK can be heard, but it's muffled, dist 25.
Tom heads off for school with Donald. Murph, still suspen looks up at Cooper, smiling.
What are we doing today?
You're staying here and cleaning the house.
Murph looks crestfallen. He looks out towards the yard. Cooper follows his stare.
I told you, Murph. There's no one to take it back to.
But what if there is, dad? What if there's something we can salvage?
Cooper thinks it over. Murph scrambles to get his shoes.
The shriek is still muffled. Cooper walks over to the wel putting in a pair of earplugs.
A line is staked off, leading down into the well below. Cooper begins hauling the line up.
As the probe breaks the surface of the water, the SHRIEK returns to its normal volume. Cooper rolls the probe out onto the ground.
The probe CHIRPS next to Murph in the backseat as Cooper spins the plane and guns the throttle and they bounce alo the dusty runway and into the air.
The tiny plane follows the mountains south.

Cooper flies in low. Los Angeles looks much the same way did in the early 20th century -- small settlements in San Monica and Downtown. Wildfires and earthquakes have shake and burned what was left of the homes in between. 26.
Cooper puts the plane down on the old highway and taxis u to a gas station. Ahead, the Coast Highway peters out and disappears beneath rows of wild grass -- Malibu has becom ranchland, once again.
An OLD MAN looks up as Cooper steps out of the plane and checks it over.
Got any diesel?
Plenty. Shame you can't eat it.
Cooper stretches the hose over to the plane.
Cooper rests a hand lightly on the controls as he follows the coast. Murph gazes out the window. In the backseat, the probe is HUMMING.
A light marine layer beneath them parts, revealing SANTA CRUZ ISLAND, a large, uninhabited island.
As Cooper soars over the island, the probe HUMS, insisten
I think it's home.
Cooper circles the island until he finds a long, flat grassland in the center of the island.
The plane bounces and hops to a halt in waist-deep grass.
Murph and Cooper climb down from the plane. Cooper slings rifle over his shoulder.
A few dozen yards from the plane they reach the tree line Murph stops, mesmerized by a patch of weeds studded with bright red -- strawberries.
Dad, what are these things?
I don't know. Don't touch them. 27.
Cooper spots something in the foliage ahead that looks a little off. He walks over.
He pokes at the undergrowth with his rifle. The rifle CLA against something metal. Cooper reaches -- it's a camoufl scrim. He gently pulls it aside, revealing a chemical transport truck.
Cooper steps back, alarmed. He brings up his rifle.
Murph?
He looks around. Murph is nowhere to be seen. Cooper curs and heads into the forest to look for him.
Cooper walks through a glade. He stops to get his bearing Leans against a tree. Snatches his hand back -- the trunk of the tree is red hot.
Cooper steps back -- it's not a tree at all, but a camouf chimney stack. He looks up: the tree is venting steam.
Cooper walks a little further, until he finds several mas tanks. The tanks are filling with a bubbling liquid -- so kind of industrial process is taking place beneath him.
Cooper finally catches up with Murph at the edge of a clearing.
Careful. There's some kind of underground facility here. We might...
Cooper notices his son is frozen, staring at something:
Standing bolt upright in the middle of the clearing, wear an old straw hat, is an eight-foot-tall military spec ROB
Is it still... alive?
Can't be. It's a marine. Haven't made them for thirty years. I've never seen one intact before.
Cooper steps closer to the robot, which is frozen. Its al frame heavily tarnished and weather-beaten. It looks like it might have been standing here for decades. 28.
Cooper moves closer to it, looking into its blackened eye He steps back, clearly a little spooked.
I think we need to go, Murph.
But can't we take it back? You could fix it up, get him to do chores.

Your mind does this to you to get you to fight a little harder to survive, to try to return to them, even if death is certain.

As he steps to the door he notices Brand watching him thr the window. She looks away.

Suddenly, as quickly as they appeared, the distortions va For a moment, the crew is silent, still spellbound by the encounter.

Release the second mouth.

Look at that.
Roth is looking through the translucent panel on the hull

It's working.
Tars finishes reeling the nuclear engines back in from th tether and locks them into place.

We're moving.
That's not possible. We haven't activated the engines yet.

They are moving, very rapidly, on a course that leads dir between the black hulks of Gargantua and Pantagruel.

It appears to be pulling us on exactly the trajectory we modelled. If we try to fight it, we could push ourselves off of that trajectory.
You don't know that.
Case stares ahead into the darkness.
We should turn off the engines. Let the swirl take us.
Listen to me.
If the modelling was wrong, then we can't be sure about anything. We need to go back.
Case thinks it over. Decides.
Shut down the engines.
The engines shut down.
SILENCE. The ship drifts for a moment in the swirl, then begins to move.
The ship accelerates as it is pulled by the irresistible force of the black hole onto an inspiraling orbit.
The crew watch as the ship hurtles around the black hole higher and higher speeds.
The sky overhead begins to spin due to their motion -- fa and faster until it becomes a blur. The ship begins to GR as it appears to be pulled in two different directions.

The ship is now speeding around the black hole at incredi speed -- one revolution every four seconds. The crew are suddenly SLAMMED against the hull in opposite directions some towards the black hole, some towards the opposite si

It's the tidal gravity caused by the black hole. It means we're right on the critical orbit.
The comms screen lights up, TONING again and again, as it receives a long garbled update. Then it shuts down. Coope drags himself along the hull until he reaches the control
We've lost contact with the relay.
Case joins Cooper at the comms screen.
While they're distracted, Doyle maneuvers himself over to the engine control. 67.
One long garbled transmission came in. Then nothing.
Case looks at the screen.
Suddenly, the ship is JOLTED as the engines fire at full power.
The crew looks over. Doyle is standing by the controls.
I'm sorry. I can't let you kill us. We have to go back.
The engines strain to fight the swirl -- but they're hopelessly outgunned by the gravity of the black hole.
Instead of reversing course, the Endurance begins to spee up, as it plummets closer and closer to the black hole.
Doyle's face sinks as he watches the controls -- on the 'volcano' model, the ship is now passing the crest and spiraling towards destruction. He has made a tragic mista
Why isn't it slowing down?
We're being pulled towards the event horizon.

ALARMS begin sounding throughout the ship as the projecte course on Roth's model shifts, showing the Endurance bein pushed up the rim, past the critical orbit and down towar the black hole's event horizon.
Case takes control of the ship, trying to fire the engine forwards to speed them back up to safety, but it's too la
The engines don't have enough power to push us back.
They would if we used it all at once.
Cooper is still trying to understand what Roth means as T locks himself into the engine compartment. 68.
What is he doing?
Saving us.
Tars tears open the engine's control panel and begins overriding it.
Tars rips out the cooling circuitry. Then, holding on tig he fires the engine.
The crew watch as Tars holds the engine, blasting it at f power into the swirl. The engine heats up white-hot.
Prime the remaining engine. When he detonates it, we'll only have a few seconds. If we overshoot we could be pulled into the bigger hole.
Roth moves to the controls.
Secure yourselves. The ship should be able to withstand the blast.
What about Tars?
As the crew watches, Tars continues to hold the engine ev as the casing around it begins to melt. Finally, it EXPLO
Tars is thrown backwards from the explosion, tumbling thr space as the ship is ROCKETED upwards.
The ship is SLAMMED by the explosion. Cooper and the rest of the crew are SMASHED against the hull. Doyle is knocke unconscious. Brand steps over to him and cradles his head trying to protect him.
On Roth's model, the course slowly pushes outward, out of the danger zone, back to the original delicate orbit.
As they near the original orbit, Case fires the remaining engine, pushing them back onto the outspiraling orbit. 69.
It's going to be close, but we're going to make it.
Brand looks at the instruments. Points to a tiny radar contact receding towards the massive black hole.
Tars. His transponder is still working.
The ship's instruments TONE every few seconds as it communicates with Tars' onboard computer.
He's being pulled toward Gargantua. We can't help him.
The crew watch, helpless, as the tones grow further and further apart. Then they stop.
Cooper looks at Doyle, anger rising. Then he looks down.
The Endurance slowly spirals back away from Pantagruel, t sky slowing as the orbit grows longer.
Finally, a tiny speck of light appears in front of the sh
Roth watches as the Endurance races back away from the bl hole and into a perfect orbit around a tiny ice planet.
Roth looks up from his screen, smiling.
We're here.
As Roth and Doyle study the frozen planet below, Cooper t in vain to signal the relay on the Earth side of the worm
Brand and Case are having a private conversation away fro everyone else. Cooper walks over.
I still can't contact the relay.
Brand ignores him at first. She nods at Case. 70.
Did you hear me? We're not able to communicate back home.
She waves him off. But she looks shaken by something.
I've already checked it. It's electromagnetic interference. We'll try again in a few hours.
Cooper begins to ask her what's wrong, but she moves off.
Roth looks up from his monitor, excited.
I've got a signal. But it's local.
A familiar CHIRP plays over the ship's speakers.
The remaining probes. We found them.
She looks at the monitor. The probes ping the ship with their locations, which pop up on the monitor. They're all clustered in one spot.
How could they all have landed in the same place?
Let's go find out.
Case programs a course that will lock the ship in orbit a the probes on the surface.
The ship settles into orbit a few hundred kilometers abov the surface of the ice planet. It can't get any closer:
The space below it is choked with hundreds of tiny moons a cruder version of Saturn's rings. The moons are hurtlin around the planet at high speed.
Brand ushers Doyle into the landing module. Cooper object
We're bringing him along? 71.
We need all the help we can get. Besides, the alternative is to leave him on the ship alone. You think he'll still be here when we get back?
Cooper steps aside, allowing Doyle onboard.
The lander detaches from Endurance, rolls over on its bel and FIRES thrusters to sink towards the planet's surface.

The moons are vastly different than our own; potato shape and only one to two miles in circumference, they are hugg in a close embrace with the ice planet, only a few hundre thousand feet from the surface.
The lander touches down on the ghostly surface of the pla
After a moment, the hatch HISSES open and the team steps out, led by Case, holding a rifle.
The team sets out, moving slowly in their cumbersome suit
Lit by the nebula, the surroundings are a little brighter than a full moon on Earth.
Not that there's much to look at. They are standing on a sea of ice, which spreads for miles. In the distance, sma rock formations break through the ice.

The probe was right. Looks like significant amounts of oxygen trapped in the ice.
Case leads the way, drawn by a signal only he can hear. H walks fifty yards, then stops on a gentle slope that lead down into a small valley. 72.
The other probes should be directly beneath us.

Case and the others begin digging into the hillside. Coop is drawn to a small mound in the middle of the valley, fo feet high. He takes out a small folding shovel and begins scraping at the ice and snow.
Case hits something solid. But it's not a probe. He digs around a little more, then reaches up and hacks away at t hillside, revealing the outline of something metal:
A door. They're not standing at the base of a hill -- it' a shelter. The crew stands back, unsure what to make of i
A few feet away, Cooper cuts enough of the mound away to reveal something flexible -- fabric caked with ice. He scrapes away the snow, revealing a bright patch of red fa

They didn't do a very good job.
Case reaches for the door of the shelter. It's sealed shu with ice. He wrenches it open.

Roth picks up an ancient vacuum sealed package of pickled egg. Virtually none of the rations have been eaten.

Cooper emerges, loaded down with several containers of Br equipment.

Get back here, Cooper. We've got a problem.

Cooper looks back. He tripped on a white plastic post sticking out of the snow. He dusts it off, to reveal a picture of a Chinese Taikonaut smiling in his flight suit This is a grave marker.

About five minutes.

Cooper looks around, their predicament settling in. Case walks over to the edge of the mine shaft.
We have to go down.
What about returning to the ship?
Not enough time. Case is right. The ice can shield us from some of the x-rays.
It would take a thousand feet of ice to shield us.
Brand gives up on the argument, sheds her equipment and c herself to the line to follow Case down into the ice.

Cooper descends into the shaft. The only light is from hi suit's light array.
He reaches the bottom of the shaft, which opens into a sm cave, the ice ribbed in wave-like patterns like the seafl

We'll never make it far enough down.
Shut up. How much time do we have, Roth?
Roth checks his watch with his usual detachment.
About three minutes or so until we're fully exposed.
The rad meter Brand is holding begins to CHIRP with activ the radiation levels are rising. The ice will not be enou to protect them.
Cooper sees that Brand has exhausted herself with the pic He takes over for her.
The drill that Case is operating GROANS as the thirty-yea old battery runs out of charge. Case casts it aside and begins SMASHING at the ice with his bare hand.
Brand is looking at the walls of the ice pocket, looking fissures. Her lights pick out something in the ice. She
Tiny black flecks. Brand, ever the scientist, forgets the predicament and begins chipping at the ice.
I've found something.

He pulls off the hand and continues to hack away at the i with the stump, trying to save his crew.
Brand is examining a piece of ice in her hands, which con several black flecks. As she shines her light on them, th FLUORESCE, giving off a tiny flicker of light, like a fir Brand steps back.
These things... they're alive.

Roth joins her, looking down at the tiny creatures trappe in the ice. Brand shines her flashlight over the ice agai but nothing happens. Roth takes the depth meter dangling a lanyard from Brand's suit.
It's not your light they're responding to. It's this--

X-rays. They feed on them and emit visible light. They've found a way to survive here.
Roth looks at the shimmering light of the tiny life-forms trapped in the ice, mesmerized.
Case hammers down with his arm, gouging a deep hole in th ice below. Suddenly, GAS sprays back up at him. He's foun the gas pocket beneath them.
Too late. Roth's rad meter begins BEEPING frantically.
Overhead, a tiny ball is orbiting into view from the dark side of the black hole -- the NEUTRON STAR.
Its humble size belies its power. As its rays hit the ice the ice CRACKLES with energy.
Brand steps back from the ice in awe as it begins to glow The microbes are absorbing the x-rays and emitting light. Within seconds, they are bathed in an incredible glow.
Even Cooper stops, awed by the beauty of the display. Onl Case is unmoved, continuing to SMASH at the ice with the broken end of his wrist. 78.
(looks at rad meter) They're absorbing most of the x-rays.
Not enough, unfortunately.
Suddenly, a CRACK as Case punches into the ice. Cooper lo down -- a great fissure has opened in the ice beneath the
Case, wait--
Case PUNCHES again. Suddenly, with a great BANG, the ice floor disintegrates beneath them.
They fall into the darkness.

As they fall, the light from the microbes trapped in the above sweeps across the inside of the cavern, illuminatin the floor of the massive cavern thousands of feet down.
The rock formations they saw on the surface are actually tip of a mountain range extending into the distance, disappearing into the ice above as if it were cloud cover

The base of the mountains is covered in a thick jungle-li foliage that runs into a perfectly-still inland sea. On t far side of the sea, another mountain range stretches int the distance, supporting the thick ice and rock cavern ro
Cooper only has a few seconds to take this in -- he is fa towards the huge inland sea below.

Suddenly, a small drag chute EXPLODES from a panel on the back of suit, slowing his fall. Airbags EXPLODE on his le and torso to cushion the impact.
Cooper SMASHES into the water.

Bubbles pour out from his suit and Cooper GASPS as his he fills with water and he begins to sink.

Cooper breaks the surface, COUGHS out water, and takes a panicked breath.
He waits. Nothing happens. He opens his mouth again and breathes in almost pure oxygen. He can breathe.
Treading water, he looks around. Spots lights in the wate below nearby -- Brand, in her suit, is sinking.
He dives down and struggles to haul her up by the suit.
Cooper breaks the surface, looks at Brand. Her mask is al broken.
Breathe. Trust me.
She refuses at first. Water is bubbling into her suit thr the open mask. Finally, she takes a deep breath.
Your suit is filling with water. I'm not going to be able to hold it much longer. I'm going to let go.

What do you mean, you're going to let go?
Take a deep breath.
Brand takes a deep breath and Cooper lets go of her.
Brand sinks. Cooper swims down, following her, ripping aw at her suit. The tear-away seals on her suit are stuck fa damaged in the fall. 80.

Cooper drags himself out of the water and onto the beach. He turns back to offer Brand a hand. She waves him off.
I don't need your help.
I thought we were supposed to be a collective organism.
She gives up and lets him help her out of the water.
They sit together, soaking wet, trying to catch their bre
Thank you.
Don't mention it.
Cooper feels the rocks beneath him, which are translucent like glass, and polished to an impossible shine.
He looks up to see Case dragging Roth and Doyle, still in their suits, out of the water.
Doyle and Roth have stripped down from their suits and ar breathing in the pure oxygen atmosphere.
Case and Cooper are pulling modular pieces from their equipment packs to form a small shelter.

Oxygen atmosphere. Pure water. Temperate climate.
You still think this is a coincidence?

I won't need one.
Why not?
Because I'm not going anywhere. This is our new home.
Brand picks up some of her instruments and a sample case hikes into the jungle.
Cooper finishes constructing the modest shelter. They loa the suits and the rest of their gear inside.
Any sign of Brand?

What happens then?
Your guess is as good as mine.

Cooper finds Brand taking samples from the tree-like life forms, which are wildly different from their counterparts back on Earth, piled in torturous coils, as if frozen in struggle to punch through the canopy to reach the light a

Look at this. I think they're the same organism at a different stage of the life cycle. (shows him the sample) It's fractal. No individual cells -- the structure repeats all the way down.
Cooper looks at the sample, then continues scanning the j around them, nervous.
Any sign of big life-forms?
The soil's been disturbed. So something's been moving. But I haven't seen anything. (notices his look) Cooper... are you nervous?
Cooper stops scanning the trees, embarrassed.
I just think we should get back to the shelter before night falls.
Overhead, the light from the ice above begins to fade -- neutron star must have orbited out of view. Night is fall

Finally, he sits down in the snow to die.
As his senses flicker in and out, he is struck with memor of his boys, so vivid he reaches out for them, crawling forward in the snow.

Cooper takes a final step. Finally, he collapses under hi ship, as the wind continues to HOWL around him.
As the snow clears for a moment, Cooper is alone on a vas arctic tundra. He will die alone.
